localization.SPELLBOOK.Tours.Multiclass.Title: Multiclass Spellcasting Setup
localization.SPELLBOOK.Tours.Multiclass.Description: Configure and manage multiclass spellcasting with proper spell slot calculation and preparation rules
localization.SPELLBOOK.Tours.Multiclass.Welcome.Title: Welcome to Multiclass Setup
localization.SPELLBOOK.Tours.Multiclass.Welcome.Conte:
Multiclass spellcasting in D&D 5e can be complex! SpellBook handles:

• Spell slot calculation across multiple classes
• Separate preparation limits per class
• Different spellcasting types (full, half, third, pact magic)
• Independent spell lists for each class
• Per-class spell slot usage tracking

This tour will walk you through configuring multiclass spellcasting correctly so SpellBook can manage everything automatically.
localization.SPELLBOOK.Tours.Multiclass.OpeningSettin:
Click the gear icon to open SpellBook Settings. This is where you'll configure:

• Which spell lists each class uses
• Preparation rules and limits
• Cantrip swapping rules
• Ritual casting behavior
• Enforcement settings

Each class in your multiclass build can have different settings. These are character-specific, so different characters can have different configurations.
localization.SPELLBOOK.Tours.Multiclass.SettingsDialo:
The SpellBook Settings dialog is organized into sections:

• **Global Settings**: Apply to all classes (enforcement, rule set)
• **Class Sections**: One for each spellcasting class you have
• **Advanced Options**: Edge case handling and special rules

For multiclass characters, you'll mainly work in the per-class sections. Each class section can be expanded or collapsed independently.
localization.SPELLBOOK.Tours.Multiclass.ClassSections:
Each spellcasting class gets its own configuration section:

• **Cleric Section**: Configure Cleric spell list, preparation, and rules
• **Wizard Section**: Configure Wizard spell list, spellbook, and rules
• **Warlock Section**: Configure Warlock spell list and pact magic
• And so on for each class

Click the class name to expand its settings. Each class operates independently, following its own rules while sharing a combined spell slot pool (except for pact magic).
localization.SPELLBOOK.Tours.Multiclass.SpellLists.Co:
Each class needs a spell list assigned:

• **Auto (Recommended)**: SpellBook automatically detects the correct list
• **Official Lists**: Standard class spell lists (Cleric, Wizard, etc.)
• **Custom Lists**: Your homebrew or modified lists from Spell List Manager

For multiclass characters, keeping this on "Auto" usually works best. SpellBook will use the official spell lists for each class. Only change this if you're using homebrew spell lists or want to customize spell access.
localization.SPELLBOOK.Tours.Multiclass.SlotCalculati:
SpellBook automatically calculates multiclass spell slots using the Multiclass Spellcaster table from the PHB:

• **Full Casters** (Wizard, Cleric, Druid, etc.): Count full levels
• **Half Casters** (Paladin, Ranger): Count half levels (rounded down)
• **Third Casters** (Eldritch Knight, Arcane Trickster): Count one-third levels (rounded down)
• **Pact Magic** (Warlock): Separate pool, doesn't combine with other slots

Your total "Spellcaster Level" determines available spell slots across all classes. You can see the breakdown in the footer of SpellBook.
localization.SPELLBOOK.Tours.Multiclass.PreparationRu:
Even though spell slots are shared, preparation is calculated separately:

**Example: Cleric 5 / Wizard 3**
• Cleric preparation: Wisdom mod + 5 (Cleric level)
• Wizard preparation: Intelligence mod + 3 (Wizard level)
• Total spell slots: As a 8th-level spellcaster

You can prepare spells independently from each class, but they all use the same shared spell slot pool when cast (except Warlock pact magic).
localization.SPELLBOOK.Tours.Multiclass.ClassTabs.Con:
In the main SpellBook interface, each spellcasting class gets its own tab:

• Click tabs to switch between class spell lists
• Each tab shows only that class's available spells
• Preparation checkboxes are independent per class
• The footer shows combined spell slot information

This separation makes it easy to manage which spells you've prepared from each class, while seeing your total spellcasting resources at a glance.
localization.SPELLBOOK.Tours.Multiclass.CantripSwappi:
Cantrips are tricky in multiclass builds:

• Each class learns its own cantrips
• Some classes allow swapping cantrips on level up
• Cantrip swapping is tracked per-class, not globally

In settings, you can configure when each class can swap cantrips:
• **None**: No swapping (most common)
• **On Level Up**: Swap when gaining a level in that class
• **On Long Rest**: More flexible house rule

SpellBook enforces these rules independently for each class.
localization.SPELLBOOK.Tours.Multiclass.PactMagic.Con:
Warlock's Pact Magic works differently:

• Pact Magic slots are separate from regular spell slots
• They don't combine with other classes' slots
• Warlock slots recharge on short rests
• Warlocks can use their pact slots to cast spells from other classes
• Other classes can use regular slots to cast warlock spells

SpellBook tracks both pools separately:
• **Pact Magic Slots**: Shown in Warlock section
• **Regular Spell Slots**: Shown in footer, calculated from other classes

This follows official multiclassing rules from the PHB!
localization.SPELLBOOK.Tours.Multiclass.CommonScenari:
Here are some popular multiclass combinations and how to handle them:

**Cleric/Wizard**:
• Full caster progression (levels add together)
• Prepare spells separately from each list
• Wizard gets a separate Spellbook tab for learning spells

**Paladin/Warlock**:
• Paladin slots (half caster) + separate Warlock pact slots
• Use pact slots for powerful smites!
• Warlock cantrips + Paladin spells

**Fighter (Eldritch Knight)/Wizard**:
• EK provides 1/3 caster levels + Wizard full caster levels
• Separate preparation for each, shared slots

**Sorcerer/Warlock**:
• Full caster Sorcerer + separate Warlock pact slots
• Convert pact slots to sorcery points!
• Rich spellcasting options

SpellBook handles all of these automatically once configured!
